item.title: Book: The Bitcoin Standard
item.description: Overview The book is logically split into two parts. Chapters 1-7: The author examines the various forms of money and its properties. They then review the economic systems and money standards employed throughout history, as well as the impact each that had on societies and their productivity. The author spends a fair bit of this part criticising Keynes and his economics which currently remain widely taught in academia. The criticism seemed repetitive at times and would have profited from being more abridged, still the influx of new economic knowledge - especially for someone without such a background - was appreciable and pleasing.

item.title: Race conditions in database transactions
item.description: This post outlines different kinds of race conditions that may occur when database transactions are executed concurrently. Race Conditions Dirty Reads Dirty Writes Read Skew Lost updates Write Skew 1. Dirty Reads Dirty Reads occur when a transaction T1 reads another transaction T2’s result before T2 has committed its transaction. Dirty reads are problematic since uncommitted writes can always be reversed or changed again.

item.title: Book: Sapiens (Chap 1)
item.description: I bought the book recently and began reading on the plane. It’s taking more time than usual to progress through because I’ve been taking notes and re-reading for retention. In fact, my primary goal is to finish the book being able to recall as many of interesting facts and theories as I could. 13.5b years ago, matter, energy, time and space came into being 13.2b years ago, matter and energy started coalescing into complex structures, called atoms.

item.title: Book: Flatland
item.description: Author: Edwin Abbott Abbott Link: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Flatland-Romance-Dimensions-Dover-Thrift/dp/048627263X One of the shorter books I have a read, a mere 100 pages were enough to fascinate me and reaffirm my long-standing belief about how little we know about the world. The book is entitled Flatland because it narrates the story of a square living in a 2D world. By 2D world, you can go ahead and imagine a flat white sheet of paper on which a square is drawn - yes that is our main character.
